div.p:
Welcome to Module 5,
where we will learn about

Sustainability as a Cycle
for Continuous Improvement.

This final module will
discuss the implications

of revisiting and revising
goals and activities.

The actions related to
this step in the cycle

include tracking and
communicating progress,

revisiting goals and making
strategic adjustments,

and sharing lessons learned
and recognizing achievements.

Your team should plan to
collect new benchmarking data
at least every six months

to determine the progress
of your activities.
Facility data can be updated all at once

in Portfolio Manager using
available Excel templates.

Periodic progress checks such
as every three to six months

will allow you to compare
actual resource consumption data
with your team's stated goals,
determine measured effectiveness,

identify mid-course adjustments,
identify best practices,

make informed decisions
about future projects,

and recognize individuals and
teams for accomplishments.
During the tracking phase,

team members should
provide regular updates

on assigned tasks and keep
clear records of activities.

Be sure to archive meeting
minutes, progress reports,
expense receipts,

survey focus group
interview notes and results,
activity photographs and videos,

and presentations and
reports to management.

A mid-course adjustment that
fine tunes your activities
and shifts resources as necessary

does not need to be
expensive or time consuming.

Several strategic phone
calls, personal interviews,
or discussions with your team

or group of department
employees, can reveal much

about what's working
well, what's not, and why.
Include a diverse group of respondents,
both demographically different

and from different
workspaces or divisions.

Assure them that their responses
will remain confidential
and help improve the project.

Look for answers to the
following questions.
Are measures yielding results?

Is data being received and
tracked in a way that is useful

for planning purposes
and project execution?

Are new policies and procedures
clear and understandable?

Are lessons learned and best
practices being documented?

What obstacles remain to
achieving the goals set?
Listen carefully to answers
that may reveal necessary corrections
to communications or policies.
In addition to reporting,

it is critical that your
team regularly revisits

and revises the action plan
to learn from and improve
on current performance.
The key steps in reviewing the action plan

include soliciting feedback
on current programming
and new ideas from the energy action team,

management and employees
including new employees.

Be sure to include both
veteran and new employees
in this conversation.
Identifying the critical factors

that contribute to meeting
or missing annual goals
including the effect of tenant behavior.

Identifying and quantifying
added value benefits

resulting from your activities
such as employee comfort,

increased productivity
and job satisfaction,

and reduced operation
and maintenance expenses.

This is also a good
opportunity to assess the need
for additional training

about sustainability
policies and procedures,

such as new operations
and maintenance procedures
designed to promote sustainability;

administrative tasks that
support energy management

such as reporting, monitoring
and data collection;

and orientation programs that
illustrate desired behaviors
for new employees.

This is also a good time to
review internal team engagement.

Teams tend to start off
with terrific energy

fueled by the excitement of
taking on an important endeavor.

Without clear goals,
expectations, roles, timelines,

and resources, as well as
recognition and celebration

for progress made, a team
could quickly lose commitment.
Strategic, consistent communication

will strengthen your employees'
understanding, ability,

and willingness to support
your team's activities.

The sustainability team
should develop a strategy

to communicate their goals,
activities, and progress
to other building users.

It will take consistent
outreach and education

to foster a long-term culture
of energy conservation.

Keep outreach fresh by
relaying program goals
and accomplishments in new ways.

For example, develop an
intranet website or blog

to post updates, tips,
and special features;
use posters and visual displays
to highlight accomplishments and savings;
display a creative milestone marker

in a central public
space to post progress;
create a special feature in newsletters
to spotlight energy-saving employees;
submit articles to print and digital media
highlighting goals and activities;

schedule regular updates
on all-hands meetings;

and host an event in
conjunction with Earth Day

or another widely attended
annual event at your facility.
To maintain support for greening efforts,
you should brief management
on performance trends and progress.

Reporting to your managers
allows them to identify areas

for continued improvement
relative to their priorities

and reaffirm their
commitment to the project.

Reporting results can
take many different forms

but any report should be
tailored to your audience.

Management will be
interested in cost savings,
increased productivity, ancillary benefits

such as improved morale and
building occupant comfort,

and the need to meet
department and federal goals.
Prepare briefing or summary documents

intended for senior management
to report on progress.

These summary reports should
include an executive summary

of the planning and
implementation process,
the qualitative and quantitative findings,

factors that contribute to
meeting or not meeting goals,
the next steps for continued improvement,

how results will impact
future programming,

and opportunities to save
more resources and money.

Try to use anecdotal quotations
to support key findings.

Incorporate photographs
taken at activities

to illustrate your accomplishments
and use clear graphics

to illustrate energy and cost
savings in your pilot project.

The long-term success of
your energy action program
will hinge in large part

on employees' consistent
support and enthusiasm.

Develop a recognition
program at your facility
to reward individuals and groups

that have contributed to
your program's successes.
This can be formal or informal
and does not need to be expensive.

It is more important that
the recognition is public
and occurs on a regularly scheduled basis.

Consider honoring
outstanding contributions

by presenting in-house
energy management awards.
Offer certificates of achievement
or publish names of energy savers
in the organization's newsletters.

Recognition can be made
to individuals or teams
based on multiple criteria

such as most innovative
energy savings project,

most participation, greatest
energy use reduction,
and greatest cost savings.
Forms of recognition can vary.
Team members can be recognized

through formal
acknowledgement, certificates,
monetary awards and cash bonuses, awards,
and media attention.
In this course

we have reviewed a number
of critical measures
for implementing sustainable strategies
in existing federal facilities.
The content of this course covered

includes the Triple Bottom
Line of Sustainability

and Fundamentals of
Sustainability Management,
broadening routine practices

to include sustainability
measures and meeting goals,

forming a multidisciplinary
team to baseline
and benchmark projects to ensure progress,

selecting and implementing
sustainability measures

with multiple benefits
and cross-cutting impacts,

and creating a structure
for continuous improvement

and resources available for
assistance and training.
There are a number of strategic objectives
that should be considered
when evaluating sustainability policies.

Policies should establish
energy accountability
by instituting a chain of command,
defining roles in the organization,
and providing the authority for personnel

to develop and implement
energy-management procedures.

Ensure continuous improvement
by developing provisions

for evaluating and updated
energy management policies
to reflect changing needs and priorities.

Align with departmental
strategic sustainability goals.

Set performance goals that
link sustainability goals

to your department's fiscal and
mission-critical objectives,

and whenever possible
reinvest energy savings
in facility improvements.
Together we can lead by example
and create a more sustainable future.
NRCan and other federal organizations

provide valuable resources,
guidance, and training

to assist you in the development
of sustainable strategies.
Examples of available resources

include the Pan-Canadian
Framework on Clean Growth
and Climate Change,

the Federal Sustainable
Development Strategy,
the Greening Government Strategy,

and NRCan's Energy Management
Best Practices Guide

for Commercial and
Institutional Buildings.
These resources can be used to learn more

about active federal commitments
related to climate change
and strategies to meet these objectives.
Other useful resources

include ENERGY STAR Portfolio
Manager and RETScreen.
Lastly, if you have any questions

about sustainable strategies
for existing federal facilities

or are interested in other
training opportunities,
do not hesitate to get in contact
with the Office of Energy Efficiency
using the contact information provided.
Our email address is
nracan.greeninggovernment-gouvernementvert.rncan@canada.ca

Our website can be found at
http://nrcan.gc.ca/greeninggovernment
Thank you for participating.
